title: Acacia rubricola
text:
Acacia rubricola is a shrub belonging to the genus "<a href="Acacia">Acacia</a>" and the subgenus "Phyllodineae" native to north eastern <a href="Australia">Australia</a>.
Description.
The shrub typically grows to a height of and has many branches and heavy foliage and a bushy habit. It has ribbed hairy branchlets with the <a href="phyllode">phyllode</a>s emerging from the ribs. The flat, evergreen and linear shaped phyllodes have a length of and a width of and are generally straight or slightly sigmoid and have a single yellow translucent longitudinal nerve that is prominent on each side of the phyllode. It flowers between August and October producing simple <a href="inflorescence">inflorescence</a>s that have spherical flower-heads that contain 20 to 35 yellow flowers. After flowering, from late November to January, chartaceous dark brown <a href="seed%20pod">seed pod</a>s will form that have a linear shape but are raised over the seeds. The pods are found up to a length of around and a width of with longitudinally arranged seeds inside. The dark brown seeds have a length of and a width of with a cream coloured <a href="aril">aril</a>.
Distribution.
It is <a href="endemism">endemic</a> to a small area on the Binjour Plateau in south eastern <a href="Queensland">Queensland</a> near <a href="Gayndah%2C%20Queensland">Gayndah</a> growing in red loamy soils as a part of heathland or open "<a href="Eucalyptus">Eucalyptus</a>" woodland communities.
